baseline_groups.claim_summary: Municipalities where the ruling party narrowly won receive significantly more government transfers per capita to politically congruent nonprofit organizations than municipalities where the ruling party narrowly lost (RD estimate ~1.39 euros/capita).
baseline_groups.notes: Primary claim of the paper. Uses 3-group political classification of organizations. Baseline coefficient is 1.39 with p < 0.001. Only the congruent (congr1) outcome row with spec_id=baseline is included; the congr2 and congr3 baseline rows are contrast/falsification tests and are classified as non-core.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Total government transfers per capita to nonprofit organizations are higher in municipalities where the ruling party narrowly won (RD estimate ~1.08 euros/capita).
baseline_groups.notes: Secondary claim. The total transfer effect is weaker (p=0.023) and less robust than the congruent-specific effect. The paper emphasizes the congruent-specific channel as the main finding.

global_notes: The paper has 4 baseline rows (congr1, congr2, congr3, total) but the core hypothesis is about congruent org transfers (congr1). The moderate (congr2) and non-congruent (congr3) outcomes serve as falsification/contrast tests where a null effect is expected. Many specs run all 4 outcomes together, so the CSV has groups of 4 rows with the same spec_id. Only the congr1 and total rows are treated as core tests. Heterogeneity splits (campaign spending, turnout, incumbency, municipality size) are classified as non-core because they test effect moderation rather than the main claim. Single-year regressions are classified as diagnostics. The spec search correctly identifies the RD as the method and the treatment is the sharp cutoff at alignm=0.
